description: The Holy Spirit Cathedral is the mother church of the Belarusian Orthodox Church and the most important Orthodox cathedral in Belarus. Originally built as a Catholic Bernardine monastery between 1633-1642 in Baroque style, it was converted to Orthodox in 1860. Located in Minsk's historic Upper Town, the cathedral houses sacred relics including the miraculous Minsk Icon of the Mother of God from 1500 and the imperishable relics of Saint Sophia of Slutsk.

unique_facts: The Minsk Icon of the Mother of God has a miraculous legend: thrown into the Dnieper River by Tatars, it was miraculously transferred by angels to Minsk where it appeared standing on the Svisloch River emanating light on August 13, 1500

The cathedral has survived an extraordinary journey: built Catholic (1633-1642), burnt in 1741, converted to Orthodox (1860), closed and used as a firefighters' gym during Soviet times (1918), reopened during Nazi occupation (1942), and finally became the central cathedral in 1961
Saint Sophia of Slutsk, whose imperishable relics rest in the cathedral, was a princess from the ancient Olelkovich family who died at only 26 years old during childbirth in 1612
The cathedral's consecration was delayed for 40 years after construction due to Muscovite invasions
During restoration in 1869, the city treasury contributed 13,000 roubles - a massive sum for that era
The icon is attributed to Evangelist Luke himself, making it one of the oldest and most sacred Orthodox icons
Unlike typical Orthodox churches, it's a three-nave basilica with a three-sided apse - rare architectural features for Orthodox buildings
surprises: The cathedral doesn't look Orthodox at all from outside - visitors are surprised by the Catholic Baroque architecture with no onion domes, revealing its original 17th-century Bernardine monastery origins
